attributes.title: Portland, Oregon
attributes.description: Coffee sleeve made by java.  Java makes it products from up to 65% recycled plastics.  Java then sells its products to Starbucks.

attributes.title: San Jose, CA
attributes.description: Home to the Starbucks Hq.  Sleeves are then organized and given a chosen destination depending on where they are needed.

attributes.title: Evansville Indiana
attributes.description:
Product arrives and is shipped to local Starbucks.  Sleeve is sold on stainless steel containers meant to last the duration of the cups life time.  

Life span is generally 1 to 3 years for most "casual" drinkers.  

Product was bought at the on campus Starbucks.
 
Consumers then dispose of the cup after the cup is either broken or they feel it is old.

Sleeve can then be recycled or trashed.

attributes.title: Consolidated Recycling Co Inc
attributes.description:
Sleeve is separated into proper plastic category.  Plastic then either melted or reused into components for companies use

By recycling these types of plastics we can slow landfills by up to 31%

attributes.title: Laubsher Meadows Landfill
attributes.description: Sleeve sets in landfill for 12 to 36 months before decomposition may begin.  decomposition for these items takes a very extensive amount of time

attributes.title: Portland, Oregon  to San Jose, CA
attributes.description: Product is shipped to Starbucks Hq.

attributes.title: San Jose, CA to Evansville Indiana
attributes.description: Starbucks Hq distributes the product throughout the US
Sleeve is sent off to recycling center
attributes.title: Evansville Indiana to Consolidated Recycling Co Inc
Consolidated Recycling Co Inc to Portland, Oregon
attributes.description: Sleeve and other amounts of recycling material are repurchased and used in new products

attributes.title: Evansville Indiana to Laubsher Meadows Landfill
attributes.description: Sleeve is taken to dump along with other trash
